christian.overview: The Lion in Tarot (particularly the Strength card and as one of the Four Kerubim) derives from Christian symbolism of the Lion of Judah and Mark's Gospel.

biblicalParallels.description: Christ as "Lion of the tribe of Judah" - the ultimate source of leonine symbolism in Western esoteric traditions.
The lion face of the living creatures represents regal majesty in divine worship.
"The righteous are bold as a lion" - courage associated with virtue.

evangelistConnection.mark: The lion traditionally represents Mark's Gospel, which begins with John the Baptist's voice "crying in the wilderness" like a lion's roar.
evangelistConnection.christSymbol: The lion represents Christ's resurrection (medieval legend held lion cubs were born dead and awakened on the third day by their father's roar).

tarotContext.strengthCard: The woman taming the lion in the Strength card represents virtue (faith, fortitude) mastering passion - a thoroughly Christian moral concept.
tarotContext.kerubim: The lion as one of the Four Kerubim on the World and Wheel of Fortune cards preserves biblical cherubim symbolism.

christian.typologicalReading: The tamed lion represents the transformation of natural power by grace - strength submitted to virtue.
scholarlyReferences: Place, Robert M. The Tarot: History, Symbolism, and Divination. Tarcher, 2005.
